 002: Basic Python Lebwohl-Lasher code.  Based on the paper 
 003: P.A. Lebwohl and G. Lasher, Phys. Rev. A, 6, 426-429 (1972).
 004: This version in 2D.
 005: 
 006: Run at the command line by typing:
 007: 
 008: python LebwohlLasher.py <ITERATIONS> <SIZE> <TEMPERATURE> <PLOTFLAG>
 009: 
 010: where:
 011:   ITERATIONS = number of Monte Carlo steps, where 1MCS is when each cell
 012:       has attempted a change once on average (i.e. SIZE*SIZE attempts)
 013:   SIZE = side length of square lattice
 014:   TEMPERATURE = reduced temperature in range 0.0 - 2.0.
 015:   PLOTFLAG = 0 for no plot, 1 for energy plot and 2 for angle plot.
 016:   
 017: The initial configuration is set at random. The boundaries
 018: are periodic throughout the simulation.  During the
 019: time-stepping, an array containing two domains is used; these
 020: domains alternate between old data and new data.
 021: 
 022: SH 16-Oct-23
 023: """
 024: # Replace 'numpy_path' with the path where numpy is installed on system
 025: cdef extern from "numpy/arrayobject.h" nogil:
 026:     pass
 027:

 062:     Arguments:
 063: 	  arr (float(nmax,nmax)) = array that contains lattice data;
 064: 	  pflag (int) = parameter to control plotting;

 066:     Description:
 067:       Function to make a pretty plot of the data array.  Makes use of the
 068:       quiver plot style in matplotlib.  Use pflag to control style:
 069:         pflag = 0 for no plot (for scripted operation);

 072:         pflag = 3 for black plot.
 073: 	  The angles plot uses a cyclic color map representing the range from
 074: 	  0 to pi.  The energy plot is normalised to the energy range of the
 075: 	  current frame.

 077:       NULL

 110:     """
 111:     Arguments:
 112: 	  arr (float(nmax,nmax)) = array that contains lattice data;
 113: 	  nsteps (int) = number of Monte Carlo steps (MCS) performed;
 114: 	  Ts (float) = reduced temperature (range 0 to 2);
 115: 	  ratio (float(nsteps)) = array of acceptance ratios per MCS;
 116: 	  energy (float(nsteps)) = array of reduced energies per MCS;
 117: 	  order (float(nsteps)) = array of order parameters per MCS;
 118:       nmax (int) = side length of square lattice to simulated.
 119:     Description:
 120:       Function to save the energy, order and acceptance ratio
 121:       per Monte Carlo step to text file.  Also saves run data in the
 122:       header.  Filenames are generated automatically based on
 123:       date and time at beginning of execution.
 124: 	Returns:
 125: 	  NULL
 126:     """
 127:     # Create filename based on current date and time.
+128:     current_datetime = datetime.datetime.now().strftime("%a-%d-%b-%Y-at-%I-%M-%S%p")
  __Pyx_GetModuleGlobalName(__pyx_t_3, __pyx_n_s_datetime); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_3)) __PYX_ERR(0, 128, __pyx_L1_error)

 150:     """
 151:     Arguments:
 152: 	  arr (float(nmax,nmax)) = array that contains lattice data;
 153: 	  ix (int) = x lattice coordinate of cell;
 154: 	  iy (int) = y lattice coordinate of cell;
 155:       nmax (int) = side length of square lattice.
 156:     Description:
 157:       Function that computes the energy of a single cell of the

 159:       reduced energy (U/epsilon), equivalent to setting epsilon=1 in

+207: cdef double get_order(double[:,:] arr,int nmax,int threads):

 253:     """
 254:     Arguments:
 255:       arr (float(nmax,nmax)) = array that contains lattice data;
 256:       Ts (float) = reduced temperature (range 0 to 2);
 257:       nmax (int) = side length of square lattice.
 258:     Description:
 259:       Function to perform one MC step, which consists of an average
 260:       of 1 attempted change per lattice site.  Working with reduced
 261:       temperature Ts = kT/epsilon.  Function returns the acceptance
 262:       ratio for information.  This is the fraction of attempted changes
 263:       that are successful.  Generally aim to keep this around 0.5 for
 264:       efficient simulation.
 265:     Returns:
 266:       accept/(nmax**2) (float) = acceptance ratio for current MCS.
 267:     """
 268:     #

 271:     # of the distribution for the angle changes - increases
 272:     # with temperature.
 273:     cdef:
